desc: Please see the shared deck page for more info.
name: Cognitive Biases and Fallacies

note_models.name: Basic-cd014

fields: decision-making or behavioral bias: Bandwagon effect
the tendency to do (or believe) things because many other people do (or believe) the same. Related to groupthink and herd behaviour.
decision-making or behavioral bias: Base rate fallacy
ignoring available statistical data in favor of particulars.
decision-making or behavioral bias: Bias blind spot
the tendency not to compensate for one's own cognitive biases.
the tendency to remember one's choices as better than they actually were.
decision-making or behavioral bias: Confirmation bias
the tendency to search for or interpret information in a way that confirms one's preconceptions.
decision-making or behavioral bias: Congruence bias
the tendency to test hypotheses exclusively through direct testing, in contrast to tests of possible alternative hypotheses.
decision-making or behavioral bias: Contrast effect
the enhancement or diminishing of a weight or other measurement when compared with a recently observed object.
the tendency to look at things according to the conventions of one's own profession, forgetting any broader point of view.
decision-making or behavioral bias: Denomination effect
the tendency to spend more money when it is denominated in small amounts (e.g. coins) than large amounts (e.g. bills).
decision-making or behavioral bias: Distinction bias
the tendency to view two options as more dissimilar when evaluating them simultaneously than when evaluating them separately.
decision-making or behavioral bias: Endowment effect
the fact that people often demand much more to give up an object than they would be willing to pay to acquire it.
decision-making or behavioral bias: Experimenter's or Expectation bias
the tendency for experimenters to believe, certify, and publish data that agree with their expectations for the outcome of an experiment.
decision-making or behavioral bias: Extraordinarity bias
valuing an object more due to an exceptional feature that does not, in itself, change the value.
decision-making or behavioral bias: Focusing effect
prediction bias: when too much importance is placed on one aspect of an event
decision-making or behavioral bias: Hyperbolic discounting
People prefer immediate payoffs to delayed payoffs, with increasing tendency the nearer both payoffs are.
decision-making or behavioral bias: Illusion of control
the tendency for human beings to believe they can control or at least influence outcomes that they clearly cannot.
decision-making or behavioral bias: Impact bias
the tendency for people to overestimate the length or the intensity of the impact of future feeling states.
decision-making or behavioral bias: Information bias
the tendency to seek information even when it cannot affect action.
decision-making or behavioral bias: Interloper effect
the tendency to value third party consultation as objective, confirming, and without motive.
decision-making or behavioral bias: Irrational escalation
the tendency to make irrational decisions based upon rational decisions in the past or to justify actions already taken.
decision-making or behavioral bias: Just-world phenomenon
decision-making or behavioral bias: Loss aversion

when the disutility of giving up an object is greater than the utility associated with acquiring it.
(see also sunk cost effects and Endowment effect).
decision-making or behavioral bias: Mere exposure effect
the tendency for people to express undue liking for things just because they are familiar with them.
decision-making or behavioral bias: Money illusion
the tendency of people to concentrate on the nominal (face value) of money rather than its value in terms of purchasing power.
decision-making or behavioral bias: Moral credential effect
the tendency of a track record of non-prejudice to increase subsequent prejudice.
decision-making or behavioral bias: Need for Closure
the need to reach a verdict in important matters; to have an answer and to escape the feeling of doubt and uncertainty. The personal context (time or social pressure) might increase this bias.
decision-making or behavioral bias: Negativity bias
phenomenon by which humans pay more attention to and give more weight to negative than positive experiences or other kinds of information.
decision-making or behavioral bias: Neglect of probability
the tendency to completely disregard probability when making a decision under uncertainty.
decision-making or behavioral bias: Normalcy bias
the refusal to plan for, or react to, a disaster which has never happened before.
decision-making or behavioral bias: Not Invented Here
the tendency to ignore that a product or solution already exists, because its source is seen as an "enemy" or as "inferior".
decision-making or behavioral bias: Omission bias
the tendency to judge harmful actions as worse, or less moral, than equally harmful omissions (inactions).
decision-making or behavioral bias: Outcome bias
the tendency to judge a decision by its eventual outcome instead of based on the quality of the decision at the time it was made.
decision-making or behavioral bias: Planning fallacy
the tendency to underestimate task-completion times.
decision-making or behavioral bias: Post-purchase rationalization
the tendency to persuade oneself through rational argument that a purchase was a good value.
decision-making or behavioral bias: Pseudocertainty effect

risk-averse choices if outcome is positive
risk-seeking choices to avoid negative outcomes.
the urge to do the opposite of what someone wants you to do out of a need to resist a perceived attempt to constrain your freedom of choice.
decision-making or behavioral bias: Restraint bias
the tendency to overestimate one's ability to resist temptation.
decision-making or behavioral bias: Selective perception
the tendency for expectations to affect perception.
decision-making or behavioral bias: Semmelweis reflex
the tendency to reject new evidence that contradicts an established paradigm.
decision-making or behavioral bias: Status quo bias

the tendency for people to like things to stay relatively the same.
(see also loss aversion, endowment effect, and system justification)
decision-making or behavioral bias: Von Restorff effect
the tendency for an item that "stands out like a sore thumb" to be more likely to be remembered than other items.
decision-making or behavioral bias: Wishful thinking
the formation of beliefs and the making of decisions according to what is pleasing to imagine instead of by appeal to evidence or rationality.
decision-making or behavioral bias: Zero-risk bias
preference for reducing a small risk to zero over a greater reduction in a larger risk.
Biases in probability and belief: Ambiguity effect
the avoidance of options for which missing information makes the probability seem "unknown".
Biases in probability and belief: Anchoring effect
the tendency to rely too heavily on a past reference or on one trait or piece of information when making decisions (also called "insufficient adjustment").
Biases in probability and belief: Attentional bias
neglect of relevant data when making judgments of a correlation or association.
Biases in probability and belief: Authority bias
the tendency to value an ambiguous stimulus (e.g., an art performance) according to the opinion of someone who is seen as an authority on the topic.
Biases in probability and belief: Availability cascade
"repeat something long enough and it will become true"
Biases in probability and belief: Belief bias
an effect where someone's evaluation of the logical strength of an argument is biased by the believability of the conclusion.
Biases in probability and belief: Clustering illusion
the tendency to see patterns where actually none exist. (pareidolia)
Biases in probability and belief: Capability bias
The tendency to believe that the closer average performance is to a target, the tighter the distribution of the data set.
Biases in probability and belief: Conjunction fallacy
the tendency to assume that specific conditions are more probable than general ones.
Biases in probability and belief: Disposition effect
the tendency to sell assets that have increased in value but hold assets that have decreased in value.
Biases in probability and belief: Gambler's fallacy
the tendency to think that future probabilities are altered by independent past events
Biases in probability and belief: Hawthorne effect
the tendency of people to perform or perceive differently when they know that they are being observed.
Biases in probability and belief: Hindsight bias
sometimes called the "I-knew-it-all-along" effect, the inclination to see past events as being predictable.
Biases in probability and belief: Illusory correlation
beliefs that inaccurately suppose a relationship between a certain type of action and an effect.
Biases in probability and belief: Ludic fallacy

the analysis of chance-related problems according to the belief that the unstructured randomness found in life resembles the structured randomness found in games, ignoring the non-gaussian distribution of many real-world results.
Biases in probability and belief: Neglect of prior base rates effect
the tendency to neglect known odds when reevaluating odds in light of weak evidence.
Biases in probability and belief: Observer-expectancy effect
when a researcher expects a given result and unconsciously manipulates an experiment or misinterprets data in order to find it.
Biases in probability and belief: Optimism bias
the systematic tendency to be over-optimistic about the outcome of planned actions.
Biases in probability and belief: Ostrich effect
Biases in probability and belief: Overconfidence effect
excessive confidence in one's own answers to questions. For example, for certain types of question, answers that people rate as "99% certain" turn out to be wrong 40% of the time.
Biases in probability and belief: Positive outcome bias
prediction: overestimating the probability of good things happening.
Biases in probability and belief: Primacy effect
the tendency to weigh initial events more than subsequent events.
Biases in probability and belief: Recency effect
the tendency to weigh recent events more than earlier events.
Biases in probability and belief: Disregard of regression toward the mean
the tendency to expect extreme performance to continue.
Biases in probability and belief: Selection bias
a distortion of evidence or data that arises from the way that the data are collected.
Biases in probability and belief: Stereotyping
expecting a member of a group to have certain characteristics without having actual information about that individual.
Biases in probability and belief: Subadditivity effect
the tendency to judge probability of the whole to be less than the probabilities of the parts.
Biases in probability and belief: Subjective validation

perception that something is true because a belief demands it to be true,
e.g. belief in psychic powers
assigning perceived connections between coincidences.
Biases in probability and belief: Telescoping effect
the effect that recent events appear to have occurred more remotely and remote events appear to have occurred more recently.
Biases in probability and belief: Texas sharpshooter fallacy
the fallacy of selecting or adjusting a hypothesis after the data is collected, making it impossible to test the hypothesis fairly.
Biases in probability and belief: Well travelled road effect
underestimation of the duration taken to traverse oft-travelled routes and over-estimate the duration taken to traverse less familiar routes.
occurs when people claim more responsibility for themselves for the results of a joint action than an outside observer would.
Social bias: Forer effect (aka Barnum Effect)
Perceiving vague personality qualifiers as highly accurate
the tendency for people to overestimate the degree to which others agree with them.
The tendency to explain other's behavior dispositionally and ignore situational factors.
the tendency for a person's positive or negative traits to "spill over" from one area of their personality to another in others' perceptions of them (see also physical attractiveness stereotype).
Common tendency to adopt the opinions and follow the behaviors of the majority to feel safer and to avoid conflict.
Social bias: Illusion of asymmetric insight
people perceive their knowledge of their peers to surpass their peers' knowledge of them.
people overestimate others' ability to know them, and they also overestimate their ability to know others.

overestimating one's desirable qualities, and underestimating undesirable qualities
AKA "Lake Wobegon effect"
the tendency for people to give preferential treatment to others they perceive to be members of their own groups.
the belief that people "get what they deserve."
a form of cultural bias in which the notational conventions of recording data biases the appearance of that data toward (or away from) the system upon which the notational schema is based.
individuals see members of their own group as being relatively more varied than members of other groups.
the tendency to unconsciously assume that others share the same or similar thoughts, beliefs, values, or positions.
Social bias: Self-serving bias (also called "behavioral confirmation effect")
the tendency to claim more responsibility for successes than failures.
the tendency to engage in behaviors that elicit results which will (consciously or not) confirm existing attitudes.
the tendency to defend and bolster the status quo.
the tendency for people to view themselves as relatively variable in terms of personality, behavior and mood while viewing others as much more predictable.
incorrectly remembering one's past attitudes and behaviour as resembling present attitudes and behaviour.
where a memory is mistaken for imagination.
recalling the past in a self-serving manner, e.g. remembering one's exam grades as being better than they were, or remembering a caught fish as being bigger than it was
confusion of imagination with memory, or the dismissal of true memories.
filtering memory of past events through present knowledge, so that those events look more predictable than they actually were.
the effect that people tend to recall more personal events from adolescence and early adulthood than from other lifetime periods.
the tendency to rate past events more positively than they had actually rated them when the event occurred.
perceiving oneself responsible for desirable outcomes but not responsible for undesirable ones.
a form of misattribution where ideas suggested by a questioner are mistaken for memory
Using an approach or description of the situation or issue that is too narrow.

a person is likely to make an internal attribution to an entire group instead of the individuals within the group.

see also: representative heuristic
name: Quoting someone out of context
an argument that attacks the person who holds a view or advances an argument, rather than commenting on the view or responding to the argument.
an argument which implies that legislation is a moral imperative.

assumes that because something could happen, it is inevitable that it will happen.

eg Murphy's Law
if an argument for some conclusion is fallacious, then the conclusion is fallacious.
premise in an argument is assumed to be true purely because it says that it is true.
using weak evidence to make a probability judgment without taking into account known empirical statistics about the probability.
assumption that an outcome simultaneously satisfying multiple conditions is more probable than an outcome satisfying a single one of them.

Attempting to introduce alternatives where there are none.
e.g. All apples are either green or not, but what about apples that are both green and red?
where a correlative is redefined so that one alternative is made impossible.
a degree of unwarranted inevitability is placed in the conclusion based on the inevitability of its premises.
where two alternative statements are held to be the only possible options, when in reality there are more.
An argument that supports both sides of an issue by using terms that are selectively emotionally sensitive.
An irrelevant conclusion or irrelevant thesis.
because something is one way, it should be.
where a "middle-man" is used for explanation, this usually leads to regressive middle-man.
the substitution of identical designators in a true statement can lead to a false one.
a fallacy that claims that if something is natural, then it is good or right.
when solutions to problems are said not to be right because they are not perfect.

Claiming that
"No proof against X --> X is true"
or vice versa
consists of assuming that things often grouped together by tradition or culture must always be grouped that way.
also called a "fallacy of relevance." This occurs when the speaker is trying to distract the audience by arguing some new topic, or just generally going off topic with an argument.
A or B; A; therefore not B.
if A, then B; B, therefore A.
if A, then B; not A, therefore not B.
an argument has two universal premises and a particular conclusion, but the premises do not establish the truth of the conclusion, because the subject may not exist.
inductive proof for a universal proposition. ("This apple is red, therefore all apples are red.")
Everybody has something to believe in. Therefore, there is something that everybody believes in.
Affirmative conclusion from a negative premise
No fish are dogs, and no dogs can fly, therefore all fish can fly.
a categorical syllogism that is invalid because both of its premises are negative.
Nothing is better than eternal happiness, and a ham sandwich is better than nothing, so a ham sandwich is better than eternal happiness.

a categorical syllogism that is invalid because its major term is undistributed in the major premise but distributed in the conclusion. e.g. All dogs are mammals. No cats are dogs. Therefore, no cats are mammals.
signifies that it has been discussed extensibly until nobody cares to discuss it anymore
a specific type of appeal to emotion where an argument is made by presenting the opponent's argument in a way that makes it appear ridiculous

Assuming that something is true/false because it has not been proven false/true.

e.g. "The student has failed to prove that he didn't cheat on the test, therefore he must have cheated on the test."
where the consequence of the phenomenon is claimed to be its root cause
claiming that two conditions along a continuum are identical
latin for: Correlation does not imply causation
attempting to avoid the burden of proof for some claim by demanding proof of the contrary from whoever questions that claim
the misleading use of a term with more than one meaning (by glossing over which meaning is intended at a particular time)
which reasons that the original or historical meaning of a word or phrase is necessarily similar to its actual present-day meaning.
where one reasons logically that something true of a thing must also be true of all or some of its parts
inferences about individuals based solely upon statistics of the group
Fallacy of the single cause ("joint effect", or "causal oversimplification")
assuming that there is one simple cause of an outcome.
occurs when an advocate appeals to an irrelevant, unqualified, unidentified, biased or fabricated source in support of an argument
asserts that a compromise between two positions is correct
the incorrect belief that the likelihood of a random event can be affected by or predicted from other, independent events
occurs when one assumes that decision makers of the past viewed events from the same perspective and having the same information as those subsequently analyzing the decision.

where not enough information is provided to make a comparison,
e.g. "product x is better than y" instead of "x sells for a lower price than y".
where different methods of comparison are used, leaving one with a false impression of the whole comparison
the assumption that the meaning intended by the author of a literary work is of primary importance
the unreasonable insistence that a concept cannot be defined, and therefore cannot be discussed.
argument in which evidence presented in response to a specific claim is dismissed and some other (often greater) evidence is demanded
assuming that a perfect solution exists or rejecting an incomplete solution
also known as false cause, coincidental correlation or correlation not causation.
submission to an argument too complex and verbose to reasonably deal with in all its details.
a low probability of false matches does not mean a low probability of some false match being found
occurs when an observer presupposes the objectivity of his own perspective when analyzing a behavioral event
When regression to the mean is mistaken for cause and effect
a fallacy of ambiguity, when an idea is treated as a real thing
it happened, so it was bound to.
where a proponent of a position attempts to cite something as an exemption to a generally accepted rule or principle without justifying the exemption
estimates of elapsed time is shorter for familiar routes as compared to unfamiliar routes which are of equal or lesser duration.
where cause and effect are reversed. The cause is said to be the effect and vice versa.
when an exception to the generalization is ignored.
when a generalization is made true only when a counterexample is ruled out on shaky grounds.
act of pointing at individual cases or data that seem to confirm a particular position, while ignoring a significant portion of related cases or data that may contradict that position
where one infers that something is true of the whole from the fact that it is true of some (or even every) part of the whole
when an exception to a generalization is wrongly called for
consists of an error in the substance of an argument (the content of the analogy itself), not an error in the logical structure of the argument
involves describing an occurrence in great detail, even if it is an exceptional occurrence, to convince someone that it is a problem
An accurate generalization with such large exceptions so that it is much less impressive than the initial statement.
when an inanimate object is declared to have characteristics of animate objects
when a person uncritically assumes that all members or cases of a certain class or type are like those that receive the most attention or coverage in the media
a commonly used phrase, sometimes passing as folk wisdom, used to quell cognitive dissonance. E.g. "drugs are bad"
Argumentum ad baculum (literally "appeal to the stick" or "appeal to force")
where an argument is made through coercion or threats of force towards an opposing party
Argumentum ad populum ("appeal to belief", "appeal to the majority", "appeal to the people")
where a proposition is claimed to be true solely because many people believe it to be true
where an assertion is deemed true because of the reputation of the person asserting it
Judging a premise based on its results
where an argument is made due to the manipulation of emotions, rather than the use of valid reasoning
a specific type of appeal to emotion where an argument is made by increasing fear and prejudice towards the opposing side
a specific type of appeal to emotion where a decision is made according to what might be pleasing to imagine, rather than according to evidence or reason
a specific type of appeal to emotion where an argument is made through exploiting people's bitterness towards an opposing party
a specific type of appeal to emotion where an argument is made due to the use of flattery to gather support
dismissing a premise by calling into question the desires of the proposer
an *argument* wherein something is deemed correct or good if it is natural, and is deemed incorrect or bad if it is unnatural
where a proposal is claimed to be superior or better solely because it is new or modern
thinking the conclusion is effected by a party's poor financial situation.
concluding that a statement's truth value is affected by a party's financial situation.
a conclusion based on lack of contrary evidence
where a thesis is deemed correct on the basis that it has a long-standing tradition behind it
where a thesis is deemed incorrect because it was commonly held when something else, clearly false, was also commonly held

Emphasizing someone's origin rather than its current meaning or context.

This overlooks any difference to be found in the present situation, typically transferring the positive or negative esteem from the earlier context.
insultive or pejorative language to influence the recipient's judgment
where adverse information about a target is pre-emptively presented to an audience, with the intention of discrediting or ridiculing everything that the target person is about to say
it would be more pleasant if; therefore it ought to be; therefore - it is
based on misrepresentation of an opponent's position
emphasizing the way in which the argument is presented while marginalizing the content of the argument
occurs when it is assumed that if one wrong is committed, another wrong will cancel it out
the argument states that a certain position is false or wrong and/or should be disregarded because its proponent fails to act consistently in accordance with that position
related to the belief that labour-saving technologies increase unemployment by reducing demand for labour
an argument which disregards hidden costs associated with destroying property of others.
argument states that a relatively small first step inevitably leads to a chain of related events culminating in some significant impact
All students carry backpacks. My grandfather carries a backpack. Therefore, my grandfather is a student.
A doctor who was outcast because he advocated hand washing in hospitals
